review.author: Brooke B.

review.description:
Yummy tacos. I had the tempura fish tacos and the pork belly. They were both delicious, especially with lime and cholula hot sauce. 
The fish was crisp on the outside and soft in the inside. The sauce had a tiny kick to it. 

The tater tots were also good. They were very crispy.

I also recommend the mint lemonade. It's sweet and refreshing.
review.author: Ada W.

review.description:
A hidden jem, only considering there are over a thousand reviews, while it is tucked away, it isn't really a secret. Believe the hype, and go here!

They do have a Credit/Debit card limit of $15, so unless you are really hungry, bring some cash. That said, the value here is great!

It was a good thing that I didn't have the cash, because to reach the $15, I bought some of their wonderful mint lemonade in addition to the taco platter.

While drinking a large cup of lemonade may not have been a great idea before a five-hour long bus ride, this stuff was still pretty amazing! It had the perfect level of sweetness, was very crisp and refreshing, and the mint added a wonderful hint of a mint! (Rhyme is not intentional) 

They also have hot sauces galore! As a lover of hot sauces, there is a whole wall of these things!  You are bound to find a sauce that caters to your tastes. As a lover of spicy stuff, I am going to dream about this! However, I would have liked them to have their own number system that indicates how spicy a sauce is (even though there is a section for super spicy ones) 

As for the tacos, I had the Pork Belly, Pulled Pork, and Cheese Steak. Tacos were of a good size, while thy weren't the largest I've had, they didn't fall apart from being overloaded as some tacos tend to do. 

Pork belly tacos were one of the best kinds of tacos I have ever had. The pork belly was so soft, tender and flavorful, I lack the words to properly describe it. There was also enough of it (they weren't skimpy with this ingredient, there was enough of it in the taco to be properly enjoyed) I will say this: when (not if) I am in NYC again, I will go back for them time and time again. 

Pulled pork tacos were not the greatest thing in the world, unfortunately. I found that the pulled pork was cold (second taco I ate) and it could have had slightly more flavor/seasoning. 

Cheese Steak was interesting. While the steak was flavorful, and cheese sauce (even though it was more like sauce) was great too, I found that these could have used just a little more steak

Other fillings were good!

Location is small, and you will likely share the very large table with someone. 

Service is polite and relatively fast!
review.author: Mark T.

review.description:
With all of the great ratings it received, I had to try this place for myself! Because we already had plans to eat elsewhere, my boyfriend and I stopped by to get an "appetizer." 

We both got a single taco- carnitas taco and the pork belly taco. It was so fresh and delicious, I seriously wanted to get a couple more! I had to control my appetite and save room for dinner, so we ended up leaving with a taste of their tacos. I honestly can't wait to go back and try their tater tots and other tacos. They've got limited seating, and and it seems like a hipster-ish place in Chinatown. It's kind of random but I like that it's within reach. The price here isn't too bad either, so it's a win-win! You'll notice they have a whole stand of hot sauces too which is a plus. Must have hot sauces for tacos- duh! I also want to try their homemade drinks. They sounded pretty good! I am definitely coming back to try other things on their menu!
review.author: Ruth K.

review.description: Food is good, space is small but communal. It's hard for the tables to stay clean with such a small space and quick turn over of diners. Don't skip the mint lemonade! Their guacamole is super good as well. It was a good meal but I won't go out of my way to eat their again.
review.author: Cari M.

review.description:
To that rando fellow juror stuck in jury duty purgatory with me 2 years ago, I am forever thankful to you for showing me the hidden gem that is Breakroom. I've probably been back at least a dozen or so times since that fateful day and let me tell you, every time has been as good as the first. 

Breakroom, I don't know what magic you put in your Tempura Fish Tacos but boy, oh, boy have you got me addicted. Seriously, guys, these are the best. damn. fish. tacos in the entire city. And anyone who knows me knows that I take my taco game v seriously, so I'd never make a statement like that without having done a lot of research (read: scarfing down random 4 am drunk tacos all over NYC like it's my job). 

Not only are the tacos fan-freaking-tastic, the prices are equally as appetizing. You can get 3 tacos--3 v decently-sized tacos that even a fatass like me feels sated from, for all those wondering--in a Taco Platter for under 10 bucks. Like, c'monnnn, game over. Breakroom, you win. 

ALSO, for all those hot sauce loving fiends like myself, you will find a whole WALL of hot sauces at your disposable at Breakroom. So pick your poison, douse your tacos with it, grab a drank (highly recommend their delish Passionfruit lemonade) and enjoy some banging food on the low low. 

And to think people say nothing good comes from jury duty!
review.author: Corinne K.

review.description:
Such a random location in Chinatown (right by the Manhattan Detention Complex nonetheless), but definitely a great hole-in-the-wall location! I was 100% overwhelmed with the variety of choices, and had to delegate the selections to my boyfriend (because I would've ordered at least half of the menu because of how indecisive I was).

FOOD TRIED:
- Breakroom Burger - I personally thought the patty could have been more flavorful, but I loved the pork belly addition!
- Taco Platter (Tempura Fish, Pork Belly, Carnitas Taco) - Tempura fish was super good, pork belly wasn't as tender as I would have liked, and the carnitas was great!
- Breakroom Fries - YES YES. Get this. If you love fries, you'll love this.

Definitely would come back to try more tacos, and maybe give another burger a shot. But overall, a quirky and cheap non-Chinese food option in Chinatown!
review.author: Jasmine L.

review.description:
This little gem was hidden quietly at the tip of Chinatown. Never would have known this place existed until yelp!
Quick and easy. Order at the counter first then grab a seat next to the giant selection of hot sauces!

1) Pulled pork sandwich (5/5)
-Meat cooked to perfection, juicy and messy! 

2) Break room burger (4/5)
-This was on the dry side for me, still tasty but wish is was juicier

3) Break room fries (10/5) 
-The best item on the menu! Comes with fries and tots with delicious cheese, jalapeños, and bacon smothered around, yum!

4) Mint lemonade (5/5)
-Definitely quenched my thirst. Like having a virgin mojito. 
-Mint + Lemon + sugar = heaven

Total cost: ~$30

Love the theme- old school video game players, duck hunt, street fighter, pac-man

Overall: this was a great quick dinner, decently priced and good portions. Next time I'll have to wear my stretchy pants for this fatty deliciousness.
review.author: Kristina L.

review.description:
This is a great hole in the wall place. Came in for the tacos which are amazing. Ordered the 3 for $10. Got a fish tempura, grilled steak, and pork belly. Couldn't tell which one was my favorite. Loved them all. 

Definitely come to this place especially if you like hot sauce. They have all these different sauces which are unique and have a different type of kick ass to it. 

Seating is very difficult since it's a small place. Must try for foodies.
review.author: Nico F.

review.description:
Pretty nice restaurant that's not too overly fancy and pricey.  The tacos are quite good, quality is on par with Chipotle.  Service is good.  Burger is not the best but definitely one of the better ones in this price range.  

Will be back when I'm looking for something else other than Chinese food.
review.author: John C.

review.description: Amazing, hands down, will go back, loved and enjoyed my experience there the food tasted amazing and I wanted more but I was so full, the staff was amazing gave my gf a free tea drink because it was her birthday. They were really friendly and even followed our food page, overall A++
review.author: Michael M.

review.description:
The hype is real! This spot serves delicious Japanese inspired food that is both aesthetically pleasing and tasty. My friend and I opted for the patio seating and had an amazing experience. The waiters attentive to our needs and the food was superb. 

Bone Marrow- So delicious! I couldn't get enough! We were given a generous sized bone marrow paired with toasted baguette slices. The next time I return, I am definitely ordering this again.
Otoro Tartare Don- The fatty tuna was fresh and paired well with the quail egg and other ingredients of the dish. 
Spicy Tuna hand roll- The roll was made perfectly. I especially enjoyed the addition of truffle oil.
Skirt Steak- The steak was so tender and perfect. The side of grilled vegetable topped with truffle oil was phenomenal. 

The presentation and taste of everything here was beyond my expectations. I am definitely coming back for the bone marrow and skirt steak as well as to sample other items from the menu.
review.author: Qi G.

review.description:
Gaijin is clearly an interesting place, where you would not be able to find traditional sushi, like the pieces you got from an authentic fish market; on the other hand, chef Mark was utilizing his culinary skills to add on top ingredients that carefully twisted the flavor. It was truly an amazing experience.

Sushi bar was reserved for Omakase only, so I happily gave up the tasting menu and went directly with Omakase. The mushroom chicken soup cleared my palate and I was more than ready to kick off my journey.

Favorite piece: Otoro+uni+caviar. I could not think of a better combination other than these. At first I thought the greasiness from uni would overshadow the fatty tuna beneath, but clearly, they made each other taste even better! Caviar was as if the pearl on the crown, adding a subtle savory flavor. Well done! I would love to come back simply for this piece by itself!

Other amazing pieces: king salmon from NZ, baby red snapper and golden red snapper, both from Japan, blue fin tuna from Spain. I was as if traveling around the globe and sampling the most delicious fish alongside.

Chef Mark was humble yet descriptive, allowing us to get to know more about his world. Astoria really got something to be proud of!
review.author: Elaine H.

review.description:
Incredible experience! Sat at the sushi bar for our anniversary and had the omakase, which was amazing. Chef Mark is super friendly and serves some of the best sushi we have had (we eat a lot of sushi). 

Worth the hour drive from Brooklyn and we plan on returning for sure. Overall, on par or better than the top omakase in the city and at a much more reasonable price. If you are looking for a great night out, come here and sit at the sushi bar, you won't be disappointed!
review.author: Daniel G.

review.description:
Soooo good. Hidden away on a random street in Astoria, Gaijin is a great Japanese restaurant with sushi and other offerings. The atmosphere is swanky but not intimidating: great for date night because the lighting is ambient AF. We weren't in the mood to spend a ton so we opted out of the sushi bar seating, but it was still a pleasant experience and we enjoyed our meal. 

The rice bowls were so flavorful and the pieces of sushi we ordered were all so good. Everything melts in your mouth in the best way. Highly recommend any of the rice bowls. Their small plates are nice--chicken skin is a popular choice, which we skipped but would gladly try next time. Instead, we got a mushroom dish and a special. Both were well-done in terms of preparation and plating. Very chef's table-worthy. Then there was the ice cream! Worth it. Ginger and milk chocolate were the choices when we went. 

The service was top-notch, fast, and thoughtful. 

The bathroom is super clean, as is the rest of the restaurant.
review.author: CHRISTINE Z.

review.description:
An excellent addition to Astoria! Gaijin serves incredible sushi. The ingredients they use are so fresh & high quality.  Great services & ambience. 

We went for the Omakase. For those who has never experienced it; it's "I'll leave it up to you" concept where the chef presents their best meal to you.  We sat at the sushi bar where Chef Mark makes the sushi in front of you. He then explains what it is. He's friendly & has superb skills with decades of experience. It's recommended that you eat the sushi all in 1 bite. The fish melts in your mouth& everything was delicious. Definitely recommend it for a special occasion/date night.
review.author: Monica W.

review.description:
wow wow wow. one of the best meals i've had in a long while. Came here with my wife for our anniversary and it was such a memorable meal. Chef Mark is a cool and friendly guy who really knows his stuff. The staff is also really courteous and friendly. From beginning to end, just a really nice, enjoyable, really tasty meal.

Ordered the omakase~ Some of the highlights of the included the HAMACHI topped with banana peppers, soy sauce, and butter (yes, butter); RED SNAPPER topped with grated apple and ginger; SAKEZUKE (salmon topped with torched chives and truffle); and KANI with uni and wasabi on top. Also, the NEGITORO TEMAKI was probably the best hand roll i've ever had.

Just a heads-up: If you're an omakase aficionado, and an absolute purist at that, you might have a gripe about Gaijin since Chef Mark leans a little more adventurous as far as his sushi offerings go (just look at some of the pics). However, his skill, as well as the quality of the food itself, are undeniable. Even though I live in Jersey, it was totally worth the drive. Thank you Gaijin!
review.author: Brett I.

review.description:
The more I do omakase, the more I realize it's not only the fish (of course that is very very important), but it is also the chef and the ambience that makes up an omakase experience. Gaijin nails that: friendly chef, good service, great fish, and a feel of community. 

When we arrived at our reservation at 6:30pm, there were two gentlemen already half way thru their omakase. Apparently they are regulars, which makes the entire place very lively since they joke with everyone. We were presented with a soup with a jumbo shrimp and mushrooms. It was presented in a small tea pot and we "cook" the mushroom by shoving it into the tea pot, pour some soup in a tea cup to enjoy, and let it sit for a bit before eating the shrimp and mushroom. Then the sushi begins. My favorite was the fatty tuna with a Maine uni on top. The chef said I looked very happy while eating it. We had about 10 pieces with a tuna handroll. Dessert was red bean ice cream. It is the only good red bean ice cream I have had in the states. It has that sand-y quality, just like those red bean desserts. The cone was crispy and my bf got an extra one with chocolate burbon flavor.

We ordered some extras at the end since we both thought it was a little small on the portion. I don't eat much and I wasn't full. Another thing is because there is only one sushi chef, depending on the crowd, it could be on the slow side. Delicious creative flavors, fresh fish, good variety and combination. You can't go wrong with the $125 omakase with its top quality and fun ambience.
review.author: Crystal Y.

review.description:
I had made reservations Friday night for Saturday, and was advised that only 5PM and 9PM was available. The cravings for Omakase were real strong, so I took the 5PM reservation. As we arrived at 5PM on the dot, only one other couple was there for Omakase as well; we basically had the place to ourselves alongside the sushi chef, Mark. The restaurant itself is really narrow yet long. Upon walking in, the sushi bar is in front and there's a few tables in the back for a la carte dining. If you wish to sit at the bar, you may only order the full Omakase. 

To start off the meal, we were each given a soup in a little tea pot with a small bowl to pour it into. In the pot was a shrimp and mushrooms. We were told to tuck all the mushrooms inside, let it cook for approximately 30 seconds, and then to pour the soup into the bowl to drink. This was a really nice way to cleanse your palette before the sushi. 
The next course was a huge oyster with soy sauce garnished with other herbs and garlic. Boy, I could've eaten at least 5 of these. The oysters were so fresh, they melted in your mouth. All the other garnishes complimented it so well. 
Then, my favorite part: the sashimi. It was roughly 10 pieces, with two hand rolls to conclude. Each piece was so unique, yet hit all of the spots. The fish was fresh and melted in your mouth, and the execution of each piece was just impeccable. My favorite was definitely the toro topped with uni and caviar. The pieces are not "Manhattan style" which I loved; in the sense that in the fish to rice ratio, the fish wins. It's a bigger piece of fish over the rice. 
To conclude, we were given dessert which was gelato from Il Labotorio Gelato, on top of a cone. Always good in my book.

I never think Omakase is gonna completely fill me, but I'm always wrong. It leaves me satisfied, yet not overly full. I love that this spot's conveniently located in Queens, so I don't have to travel to the city.
review.author: Jessica L.

review.description:
I have to admit, this was a very interesting/modern interpretation to sushi. It looked very much like sushi, but the flavors were completely different from you would expect. Chef Mark, who is from Chicago, is not Japanese but his interpretation of sushi was very fascinating, I give him points for his creativity. I came here with some friends and we sat at the bar, right in front of Chef Mark and we did the Full Omakase which was $125. The restaurant itself is very sleek and modern, it had a warm, clean and modern atmosphere, the service was also very knowledgeable and very friendly. Overall, my meal was good, I enjoyed the flavor and texture of the seaweed that was used but the last few pieces towards the end of the meal came off on the salty side. I also wish the rice had a little more seasoning, I felt all the flavor was solely concentrated on the fish that the rice was kinda forgot.

The food:

Agedashi Tofu- This was a nice starter, it was nice and light with a nice crunchy exterior and nice subtle interior. I thought the balance of the soy and tofu was great. https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=A1SOwYeZi_lMSC_rUTAg2w&userid=Y_iTTjKvV5hLy-880SZzlA

Dobin Mushi- Well, the dish is served in a tea pot and this was such a fun starter. You add the mushrooms to the tea pot and you let it steep. There was seafood inside that cooked perfectly and the broth left behind was so aromatic and flavorful. https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=D4q_xpKTprkB1hq-g2YEdw&userid=Y_iTTjKvV5hLy-880SZzlA

Shimaji- Striped Jack. The first three nigiri pieces were excellent. Shimaji is one of my favorite pieces and the one here was so silky and the flavor profile was spot on. https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=PkTEDtBxHqt-op0HuXDi9Q&userid=Y_iTTjKvV5hLy-880SZzlA

Hirame- Fluke- I am normally not a fan of fluke since it has such a mild flavor but the one here was done really nicely. https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=wMXkYelKNNkBADYisoezlg&userid=Y_iTTjKvV5hLy-880SZzlA 

Hamachi- Yellow Tail, Butter and Pepper. The idea of putting butter on sushi seems so crazy but it totally worked. It added such a unctuousness to the sushi. I say this was a "oh shit" piece. https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=83rUMzmOlrM4Bmy7xXGbOw&userid=Y_iTTjKvV5hLy-880SZzlA

Madai- Yuzu, Fuji Apple. This was very unique to add a sweet component to the Madai. It was a good combo of the fish with the sweetness of the apple. https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=QQHM4l_rGl-hOzxYSobrdg&userid=Y_iTTjKvV5hLy-880SZzlA

King Salmon- Grilled Maitake, truffle oil. The piece looked stunning. The maitake really added a nice texture and the hint of the truffle oil was a nice addition. https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=47AxIcWM6I4NL8ycw9x2ZQ&userid=Y_iTTjKvV5hLy-880SZzlA

Blue Fin Tuna- The tuna had a wonderful texture and the mushroom and green onions paired nicely. https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=ZL55YRFKnzmob8kbdofgDg&userid=Y_iTTjKvV5hLy-880SZzlA

Otoro- Plum Wine, wasabi. I was expecting this to amaze me but the otoro didn't have as much flavor as I was hoping. https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=Axjp2z9CCqOWbzSYb9K_0A&userid=Y_iTTjKvV5hLy-880SZzlA

Toro Caviar Uni- It was a good piece but with the list of ingredients, I was expecting it to be spectacular.  https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=VTDHDigtpDsaEpyIwOZh9g&userid=Y_iTTjKvV5hLy-880SZzlA

Spanish Mackerel- The fish was done nicely, it had a nice straightforward flavor. https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=s70NfPttt5T95h6Xb3mqFw&userid=Y_iTTjKvV5hLy-880SZzlA

Caledonian Blue Shrimp with Uni Egg- I just remembered the raw shrimp, it looked amazing and I thought it would blow me away but the Uni flavor was surprisingly not at the forefront. https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=vC9S1hG_PlxiuA_ucw7K8g&userid=Y_iTTjKvV5hLy-880SZzlA 

Uni Ikura- This another piece I was hoping to love, I just remember it being salty. https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=U0mLmVFlwU5ERxxGy4eszA&userid=Y_iTTjKvV5hLy-880SZzlA

Tamago Anago- The seaweed on this was great but for me, the egg and eel were just OK and it was salty. https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=n1g4OdkgvIzclpnEQwlxkA&userid=Y_iTTjKvV5hLy-880SZzlA

Tuna Tartar Hand Roll- The chopped tuna and the seaweed was great but this came off salty. https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=g2r4PSB381kyVAb0WXXv0A&userid=Y_iTTjKvV5hLy-880SZzlA
review.author: Ben L.

review.description:
I came here with my husband, cousin and fellow Yelper Ben L. on a Monday night. We arrived right as they opened and the place was empty. I had made reservations ahead of time and requested the full omakase. The place is very modern and the sushi bar is a beautiful marble.

We were greeted promptly and sat right away. They don't have their liquor license yet, but you can bring your own alcohol. We didn't know this, so we settled for tea. 

The omakase started with an amuse bouche of age tofu. It was a nice way to start the meal. It was followed by a steep your own soup served in a cool little tea pot. While we had our appetizer, we met Chef Mark. He was super friendly and funny. He was easy to talk to and we had a light conversation about how he became a sushi chef.

The sushi course started shortly after the appetizer. I honestly can't remember what the pieces were because they were so intricately prepared. Chef Mark is so creative with his preparation and seasoning. It's definitely not traditional nigiri. We were so blown away with the first 3 pieces. Exceptionally prepared and you can tell he thought of the flavors so carefully. 

If the rest of the sushi were like the first 3 pieces, I would've easily given this place 5 stars. But somewhere after the 4th or 5th piece, we started to notice the flavor got saltier. There was also some confusion with seating at the sushi bar and we noticed Chef Mark become less talkative after that. He even forgot to describe a piece or two. He also let his sous chef sauce and season the last half of the meal. 

Overall, I would love to come back to try the omakase again. I'm also very curious about their bone marrow. But I'll wait a few months for the kinks to sort out.
review.author: Michelle A.

review.description: One of the best paces to enjoy quality meal in Queens. They have the best bone marrow dish I have ever tried. The service is beyond words and the decor and the ambience are just the perfect combination of future and just the right amount of hint of the past. Our waiter was friendly and professional. The place certainly grants guests with acquired taste for excellence and even if you are new to future dining one can certainly appreciate the demeanor the establishment possesses. I recommend this place to everyone who is eager to push the limits of our palate. Also they have an amazing backyard to top it all of.
review.author: Sebastian B.

review.description:
Let me start off by saying that I can not believe I live 2 doors down from this restuarant. I wish I had to $$$ to dine here everyday. Sadly I don't but I will be coming back to try their omakase.

My husband and I finally had to chance to check this place out, and wow the food just blew me away. Jusy want to note that they don't currently have their liquor license so this place is BYOB at the moment. That's awesome!

They start you off with a complimentary dish called agedashi tofu. It's just one little piece of tofu but my husband and I ate and slurped everything up. Portion are a bit small for the price, it's fine dining, but still so good! With $60, we tried all the small dishes like the skirt steak skewers, karage, salmon sushi, and a temaki. For the higher end donburi we got the tuna one that I thoroughly enjoyed. It had a quail egg on top. What can beat that. 

Ambiance is super nice and although we got a table the sushi bar seems to be where it's at. Reservation is highly recommended because of the limited seating. Service is impeccable and the server was knowledgeable on all the dishes. 

I will definitely be coming back to try to full omakase because that is what everyone is raving about on Yelp.
review.author: Hayong L.

review.description: Astoria doesn't deserve this place. This place is amazing. This is the best Japanese food I have had in my life. Better than anything I tired in Japan. The bone marrow was my personal favorite. I have already visited them twice. Chef Mark is a class act. Gaijin means "foreigner". He is not Japanese but my god, the man better receive a Japanese passport for his work.
review.author: Nabeel A.

review.description:
Clean and modern ambiance, amazing and creative sushi, and a friendly sushi chefs who are passionate about what they do. We will definitely be back here!

If you are planning on doing omakase, make sure to come hungry!

Food, Service, and overall experience: 5/5
review.author: David H.

review.description: So I heard about this please thru my friend who is a sushi fanattic and we've been going to sushi sake and sushi of Gary in the city for a while but after hearing about this place we figured we give it a shot we go in and we were immediately greeted with a very friendly hostess and immediately seated at the sushi bar - fast fwd amazing from the truffle sushi to the black caviar on sushi I can't explain the quality and craftsmanship that I got on my plate Mark and Andrea are two of the most gifted sushi chefs and sweetest people to sit down and talk to not only were they awesome to talk to but they give us a full breakdown of all the types of fish . Definitely coming back
review.author: Allen G.

review.description: Love this place! So amazing, the chefs ryan, mark and Andrea are fantastic!! Such amazing sushi, for me, a person who usually doesn't eat fish it was fantastic! I ate every piece! Some of the fish were like butter!! Can't wait to come back with my family!
review.author: Angelica H.

review.description:
Little gem in Astoria. Got the 6 piece omakase with 2 dishes and the fish of the day
Although service is a little slow here for omakase it is worth the wait. Next time I will definitely put down for bar seating if I could
review.author: Jeffrey C.

review.description:
I first found out about this location through my friend's posts when they first opened, the presentation of all the dishes immediately attracted my eyes, but I was still skeptical until I read about Gaijin again in the Thrillist of best omakase in NYC where the restaurant was featured in its price category (obviously, you have other famous oamakse such as Nakazawa, Yasuda, Ichimura, etc.). 

I went there last night to celebrate my anniversary with my husband, reservation was so easy over Yelp, after all the frustration with some of the other restaurants, I am loving Yelp again and restaurants that utilize Yelp. Ultimately, I prefer no detour before I am on my way. 

We pulled up at 6:30 right outside Gaijin (if I understand it correctly, it means "outsider" in Japanese, right?) and was able to park the car. Gaijin is on the ground level of a "luxury apartment", to my surprise, it's a shining star in the neighborhood and even across from several other Asian restaurants.

The star server of the night, SK is a lovely host, entertainer and provided excellent service. He took us to sit in front of Chef Ryan who served our omakase, Chef Mark was serving two other patrons at the moment, but he nodded to greet us. 

We received a wonderful bottle of Junmai from the owner, SK patiently walked us through several ways of sipping/drinking it, we ended up having a few glasses with him and Chef Ryan.

First thing first, we started out the tasting menu with a soup, served in a nice stone tea pot, we were told to pour it onto a cup and sip it, after a few pours, we ought to eat the shiitake mushrooms and daikon. It's got a nice rich flavor, different from your typical miso soup, but it was slightly too heavy as a starter. 

A typical omakase menu starts with large fish, light to heavier/richer flavors, and ends with sweeter dishes. We had in the order of a yellowtail, salmon, tuna, toro, saba/amber jack kind of fish, sweet clam and eel. Gaijin also follows the rule, but they break it by adding a French kick to it according to Chef Ryan, their head chef studied a little bit of French cuisine, so they incorporate it into sushi, what a brilliant idea! 

The salts, sauces, spices, things like roasted garlic slice, caviar, scallion, all made a huge difference in each piece of sushi, the tuna and salmon were lightly burned by torch fire, we used our fingers to take the sushi and it was a wonderful experience, but each nigiri was very, very delicate, if only the rice would hold up better, it's got a lighter taste (not heavily sweet or vinegar-sour), everything together tasted like one harmony.

That piece of freshly opened clam was one of the sweetest things I ate, I also loved how the uni and caviar played a game with the toro, the whole thing melted in my mouth, the sardine types of fish were also very different but very good. 

I did tease Chef Ryan because he didn't serve tamago at the end, he said he actually made tamago moments ago and offered to us after the anago (which was supposed to be the last course). It was good but more typical than special, I had the custard type at Nakazawa (which he made for 10 years at Jiro's restaurant in Japan) where they would infuse yam in the eggs, but hey, not everyone makes that.

Chef Ryan is humber, doesn't talk a lot but was fun to talk to, he'd worked at 15 East before, and also with chefs that came from a Masa background, he has a lot of fun creating omakase, I think what makes a chef a great chef is when they have fun doing what they do, right?

I'll bring my friends in for another tasting and I hope to try something different.
review.author: Weili H.

review.description:
A delicious splurge it was. 

Omakase with Chef Mark was a fun and tasty experience. Each piece was carefully crafted with an east meets west taste. Some of the most fresh selection as well, just melts in your mouth. 
The two fine gentlemen that waited on us were both friendly and sweet. Chef Mark is also delightful and fun to talk to, making the experience personal. 
We'll definitely be back.
review.author: Susan C.

review.description: I went here with a friend because we wanted sushi, we never expected such incredible service and the friendliest staff. Our server who's name was Bun gave us amazing recommendations such as the 6 piece Omakase Set and the Maitake. Definitely stop by its worth every single penny.
review.author: Stephanie M.

review.description:
We tried a *lot* of dishes at Kitchen 79, but two things really stood out to me: the curry puffs and the spicy pork knuckle. It was worth the visit just for those!

We had a reservation for four, but my friend and I arrived an hour early, so naturally we got a head start on appetizers. We tried the aforementioned puffs, the spring rolls, the calamari, and the fried tofu. The others ranged from okay to good, but the puffs were the only thing we doubled up on after trying. There's not much to dislike about the dish!

Later, once our other friends got there, we got entrees for ourselves. I went with the spicy pork knuckes, which advertises two different heat sources. They weren't lying: it's hot. The pork itself was tender with the right amount of chewiness, and our free check-in lychee mimosas helped offset the spice.

The menu at Kitchen 79 is giant, and filled with items you won't find at your typical Thai restaurant. For that reason in itself I'd be happy to return, but it doesn't hurt to know I've got some curry puffs waiting for me as well.
review.author: Brennan L.

review.description:
First : finding parking in this area is absolute 
*H E L L. You've been warned! Also, I believe the 7 train runs here so that's an option. 

The store front doesn't have a sign above, only a circle inside the window that says "79" so it may be hard to find for some and it's also located within the block and not on the main Ave. 

This restaurant is absolutely gorgeous, the pictures do make it seem bigger than it is. The minor details are simply exquisite and there's no doubt that a lot of time and money was spend on the decor. The seats are leather, the chandeliers are stunning and the overall layout of the restaurant is great! They made such good use of the limited space they do have.  The bathroom is so cute. The waiters have denim aprons and the dishes are served in either square or oval shaped plates. The water is served in beer glasses and there is a full bar (with a check in offer). 

Upon arrival, (7:30pm-Saturday), my bff and I were greeted right away and seated. We opted for the love seat which I absolutely adored. A very unusual seating area which would be perfect for a couple/date night. The staff was very helpful with the questions I asked, kudOs. 

What we got for under $50: the menu has so many options, it was hard to choose a dish! 

Curry Puffs: delish
Dumplings: moist, savory, mMmmMm

My friend got some worth of pineapple and chicken dish with white rice from the "wok" section. It was perfectly sweet and yummy!
I got the 1st option of fried rice (I forgot the name but it's the first one in that section). I opted for medium spicy and got it with shrimp. This was really flavorful. I felt as though the rice was a bit grainy and the portion was unusually small. 

Teatree Fried Ice cream: they do serve this with flames. Eh, it tasted smoky and burnt. I didn't like the taste of the outter shell but the ice cream itself was good. 

Thai Ice Tea - large portion and very good. 

Overall: beautiful ambiance and good food.
review.author: Alicia B.

review.description:
On my second visit after awhile, the staff was very accommodating to our large group on a Friday night. The food was still good. I like how their Thai/Green Iced tea is served in such large cups. However I do prefer the iced tea elsewhere (Dek Sen, Chao Thai). 

I was most excited to order the lychee creme brûlée as that was my ultimate memory from the previous visit. I was unfortunately disappointed when they just dropped the check on our table and didn't tell us the kitchen was closing. Normally the staff warns you in advance and asks if you'd like to order anything else, but they just said the kitchen was closed after we said we wanted to order dessert. I know the creme brulees are premade in advance. You just dust it in sugar and torch it. I'm a bit miffed by this since this was the only reason I came here but aside from this, everything else was still good.
review.author: Buena Y.

review.description:
First time visiting and overall a good experience. 

With a yelp check in you can get a free lychee mimosa. Everyone in my group got one.  

Food :

- the Som Tum Poo Dong Salad (papaya salad with the salty crab ); the salad part was pretty flavorful and tasty. The salty crab didn't really add much to the experience and I could have gone without it, perhaps I did not eat the crab the right way. 

- the Larb Gai Larb Moo Salad; pretty good and flavorful, similar to the other nearby Thai restaurants. 

-Peek Gai Mak Khamin Tord (chicken wings); they had flavor combination of salty, savory and some slight sweetness. I wish there was a side of dipping sauce to really soak them in. 

Drinks:
-Thai iced tea and coffee come in huge glasses. For the price definitely worth it. 

The atmosphere and decor:
Clean and modern. The chairs are low and soft, quite comfortable to sit back in.
review.author: Suzanna H.

review.description:
Found this place on Yelp randomly and was drawn in by the high reviews and close location so I decided to give this place a try. The Jackson heights and nearby Elmhurst area is flooded with Thai food, so there's a lot of competition in this cuisine in the area. However, I've tried Ayada Thai and SriPraPhai several times, unimpressed, I decided to give this place a shot.

As others have said, this place feels much more upscale.. similar to a restaurant you'd find in the city.. but for much cheaper prices. The lighting inside is a little dark for my preference, but definitely enjoyable for a romantic date. I started off with a Thai tea.. because.. who goes to eat Thai food without enjoying a Thai tea on the side? (Did you really go to a Thai restaurant?) $3 is $.50-$1.00 more expensive than how much other places charge for Thai tea, but I assure you that the quality of this tea is one of the best in the area. The portions.. is.. fair, most of my cup was ice and nothing compares to the LARGE jug of Thai tea from Ayada Thai. We also had the calamari for appetizers which was underwhelming since the batter was not crispy.. it was actually quite soggy even though it was warm and evidently just came out of the kitchen.

My go-to Thai cuisine, that I get at every restaurant without fail is Pad See Ew.. so I would say I am some type of Pad See Ew expert.. this, was done correctly. The noodles are soft but chewy, flavorful, not too oily, chicken was soft and not rubbery tasting.. and the portion was right. My friend had a curry option (I don't remember the name exactly) but he enjoyed it though it was not something he typically liked having (so that is a plus).

Overall, I would love to come back. Great food for a great price, at a convenient location!
review.author: Maggie Z.

review.description:
The restaurant is right at the corner of Roosevelt and 79th St. 

We went on Sunday around 3pm. The place was about half full. We got the Peek Gao Make Khamin (fried chicken wings), Larb salad a d Gaeng Massaman Curry. Everything was delicious, the Larb salad was on par with other Larb salad I have gotten at Thai restaurants on    Woodside ave a few blocks away. 

The Thai ice tea and Thai coffee comes in big beer mugs. Keep in mind, when they ask how spicy you want your dish, spicy is very very spicy!
review.author: Gaoxiang C.

review.description:
4.5 Stars

Excellent food, this was some of the best Thai I've had in awhile. I loved the somtum thai, it was fresh, well-seasoned and delicious. I enjoyed it so much, I ordered a second one to take home. 

The pad woon sen was pretty delicious too, The glass noodles had plenty of flavor and were paried with beef, woodear, bell pepper, scallions, and other vegetables. 

The Thai iced tea came in a pretty big mug and was excellent as well. It was on the sweet side, but very good. 

The only dish I tried that was harder to eat was the gaeng tai pla (a curry dish with shrimp, mackerel and vegetables). The server warned that this southern thai style dish would be really spicy and a bit fishy. He was right, even though the heat was toned down by request, it was still hot and the mackerel flavor did permeate the dish. This dish would definitely be an aquired taste. 

Overall, wonderful food. Lots of options to choose from ranging from noodles, curry, curry, to sauteed and specialty dishes. I would definitely like to go back and try more menu items.
review.author: Nikki L.

review.description:
I would rate Kitchen 79 four and a half stars.

I stopped in for the lunch special which included an appetizer and main course for under $8.50. I started with the kanom jeeb. This dish was very similar to shumai without shrimp.

For the main course, I ordered the Thai red curry with chicken. The flavorful profile was magnificent. Spiciness from the curry, sweetness from the coconut, a hint more of bitterness and sweetness from the basil, and earthiness from bamboo. All in all, it was a very well balanced dish.

The service was quick and attentive. The staff was friendly and polite. The decor is and sleek and modern; it could easily be mistaken for a trendy cocktail bar.
review.author: Joseph T.

review.description:
Kitchen 79 is a small Thai restaurant with a great modern appeal, smacked in the middle of residential buildings.  Having said that, it is quite difficult finding street parking, especially if you come here on a Saturday night like we did.  

Both the exterior and interior of the restaurant are pretty contemporary and upscale-looking.  The lighting of the establishment is a bit on the dim side, but it works well with the semi-gothic looking furniture and decor.  We situated ourselves by the bar because we found the tables to be a tad close to each other, given the size of the space and the number of tables the establishment tried to fit in there.  Unfortunately, what came with our own privacy was getting knocked continuously by passersby.

We next checked in like avid Yelpers and claimed our free lychee mimosas, which were delicious (I mean, they're free).  We then ordered the steamed dumplings appetizer, the stir-fried glass noodles and mango salad to share.  Every single spec of food was devoured by us, because they were that tasty.  Service was pretty good as well and a plus that there is a TV by the bar area to keep us entertained while chowing down.  

I'd definitely recommend this place.  We walked in on a busy night, so I'd advise trying to make reservations in advance.
review.author: Maggie L.

review.description:
Needed some late night food and found this place. I ordered the phad Ka prow which was really good no the curry puffs which were also good but just softer than our normal Thai place. It's was $17+ for both.
Glad they were open late. Just walked in to pick it up and they were very friendly on the phone and in person.
review.author: Liz S.

review.description: This place has great ambience (lighting, music and decor), great service and really good Thai food.  The sauce on their pad thai isn't my favorite (only because I prefer a sweeter sauce, which I also feel the dish could use more of), but their curry puffs are really good, as is their fried rice with pineapple in it. The prices are also great. Been here a couple of times already and know that it will definitely be my go-to when in Jackson Heights.
review.author: Athenais A.

review.description:
My boyfriend and I came here for lunch. Pretty place. We checked in on Yelp and got lychee mimosa. We got them non-alchololic. This place still can't beat Arunee which is right up the block. 

I was a bit disappointed to see dust on the bottom of my glass. My boyfriend's plate was chipped. This made me upset.

The food was alright. The crab rangoons are great! The chicken fried dumplings are okay.

The guay tiew pad kee mao was alright, and my spicy basil fried rice was decent.

I'd rather go to Arunee, bigger portions, and better tasting food.
review.author: Dimple K.

review.description: Very reasonable prices for lunch. $8 Im starting to notice that most if not all Thai places have great lunch specials. I would return if I'm ever in the area
review.author: Francisco H.

review.description: The food is delicious.. the appetizers are super good.. niece ambience. Quick service.
review.author: Pamela B.

review.description:
Kitchen 79 looks and feels a little more upscale than other Thai places in the area bit without much of a price difference. Definitely very dark if that helps you get an idea. There are candles but you still can't really see your food if you're there at night. I just like to see my food. It's like a guessing game when it's that dark: "Oh, some chicken... that's squid... hmm onion... nope a pepper!" but everything tasted good so we made it through!

Besides eating in the dark, the food was good but not mind-blowing to me. Not all food is or has to be though. Definitely solid food with fair prices and a more sophisticated ambiance.

That being said, I do think there are a lot of other great places in the area. I personally prefer SriPraiThai, Ayada, and Arunee overall vibe and food wise. If you're looking for a Thai spot to bring a date, maybe this is your joint. It's dark enough she may not see that booger in your nose or that weird stain on your shirt you couldn't get out before leaving the house.
review.author: Chris B.

review.description:
I stopped by for dinner with friends on a Sunday night. It was fairly busy and there was only one waitress for all the tables. It took her a while to get to us and she was very impersonal so I bumped the rating down a star. My friends and I were seated at very uncomfortable seats. We felt like we were sinking in the seats. I had to sit at the edge of my seat to feel a bit more comfortable.

 I ordered:
- Thai iced coffee (If you like your coffee bitter but sweet, you should try this)
- Yum Ma Mong salad (Such a refreshing salad. It's a bit on the sour side but that's what makes it good)
- Lychee Crème Brûlée (I'm always down for some crème brûlée. The lychee flavor added a nice twist to it and I definitely recommend)

I must say that I am not big on Thai food. I feel like maybe it's because I always associate it with pad thai (so sick of it after eating it one too many times). However, I know I'll be back for more at Kitchen 79.
review.author: Nina F.

review.description: Excellent every time. Fast and friendly service. Delivery is always hot and well-packaged. Actually, I love this place so much that I ordered it practically every week for months and had to be cut off by my partner. (I've fallen off the wagon, though; placing an order in a minute). Definitely worth a try!!!
review.author: Caitlin M.

review.description:
My family and I really love this place. It's a hidden gem with delicious food and good prices. The staff is very friendly.

The only issue I ever had with them was that one time our brown rice smell funky and tasted weird and when we told the waiter he just gave us a blank look and just said okay... It was awkward and there was no resolve, which annoyed me because we eat there once a week so I felt unappreciated as a loyal customer.
review.author: Zarin A.

review.description:
This place is well decorated, a warm hearted service and attentive staff. The food are also delicious. Especially The Tom Yum Fried Rice, it is the best dish ever!! Really recommended to try. Khao soi is the dish that comes with both  fresh and crispy noodles, which makes it so unique and  the soup was rich and flavorful. We finish our meal with the Lynchee Cream Brulee, and we Win ;)
Definitely come back!!

The Thai Ice Green tea is also yummy.
review.author: Supawadee T.

review.description: Great food, ambiance, desert, service. Gotta come here. Everything was served timely with great prices as well. Didn't break the bank for a 5+ Star meal.
review.author: Adam d.

review.description:
well worth the subway ride from 163rd street. tiny, tiny, standing room only kind of place -- i walked right by and i was navigating with the YELP app so it's not hard to miss. The downsized "shorty" more than enough sandwich unless your planning on skipping dinner. 

Once I got past their sandwiches aren't "traditional" crispy skinned porchettas, I was amazed. Little sloppy especially if you dump on the hot sauce (i did) but ROCKET PIG provides plenty of napkins. 

smoked, spice-rubbed pork on ciabatta roll with red onion jam and mustard sauce on a chewy ciabatta roll with a house-made pickle spear and a side of ROCKET PIG hot sauce -- mmmm good. count me in.

ginger beer was the perfect compliment.
review.author: Scott T.

review.description:
the Rocket Pig Sandwich was pretty damn great. I had it for $14 which was really worth it. Its texture and ingredients were packed. There's no complaint about it. 

The place was nice and the service was really fast. My wife enjoyed here a lot. We're definitely coming back for more.
review.author: William O.

review.description:
AMAZING! I expected a great pork sandwich but this was exceptional! This place is simple enough, just offering a delicious sandwich in two different sizes, tucked in the back behind Trestle. There are no tables for sitting but counter tops inside and outside for a casual quick bite.

I got the pig-nic because I wanted to try as much as possible and that amount of food was more than enough. In a to-go box,it came with an original size sandwich, a dill pickle, vinegar based coleslaw, choice of chips, dessert (offerings of a brownie, cookies and bacon caramels) and a soda.

Everything was delicious! The original sandwich was of course the star of the show. SO FREAKEN GOOD. The ciabatta bread was perfection with the tender, smoked pork mixed in with the mildly sweet red onion jam, countered by the acid of mustard sauce. Their side of hot sauce brought it to a great spicy level. It was just so good. The original size is huge and towards the end my stomach was stuffed but I would get that size over and over again without a doubt. I would just stuff it down my throat because it is too good to waste. 

I went with a couple of friends so I was able to try a few of their desserts. A perfect sweet end to a savory meal. The bacon caramel was melt in your mouth. The hazelnut chocolate mousse cookie was decadent. I loved it all. I think the only thing I didn't love were their North Fork chips because the sour cream and onion had a sweet twang to it but regardless, the sandwich more than made up for it. Next time, it will just be the sandwich and myself, together forever.
review.author: Michelle L.

review.description: "Umph" is the noise I made when I took my first bite into Rocket Pig's sandwich. These guys reeeeeally know how to roast pork. The offerings here are simple. Basically everyone comes in to get a pork sandwich, available in 2 sizes with other small sides and dishes. There's standing room only, but you'll eat this sandwich so fast you won't need a seat. The little hazelnut cookies are also pretty sweet and yummy. Blast off!
review.author: Claire W.

review.description:
Simple.   Simple isn't easy to execute.  If you do one thing and it isn't perfect there are no excuses.  Rocket Pig does one thing beyond perfection.

The Rocket Pig sandwich was the best sandwich I have had in years.  It wasn't just the best it was something I finished and instantly craved more of.  
My wife wasn't hungry but shared the original with me.  She was only going to have a taste.  Nope.  She ate her fair share and more.

The sandwich comes on a fresh ciabatta, with a lot of amazing roast pork.  The pork is tender, a little spicy and literally mouth wateringly perfect.  The sandwich comes with "mustard" which is an aioli that has no mustard taste which is good for me.  I hate mustard but loved the aioli.  There is an onion jam which adds a sweetness and hot sauce which balances everything out.  

Simply perfect.  A must try.
review.author: Jeff G.

review.description:
Cuisine: 10
Service: 5
Decor: 8
Value: 9
Overall: 9

Bam! We have lift off! Easily one of my favorite meat between two pieces of bread found in any sandwich shop throughout the entire city. The menu is tiny with two sizes for the Rocket Pig Sandwich (original & shorty), a salad, a soup, and a few miscellaneous items. I like these types of specialty restaurants because they stick to what they do well, and what they do well is basically a massively flavorful and fork tender BBQ pulled pork, paired with amazingly sweet caramelized onions and mayo based sauce, tucked into a pillowy ciabatta bread that elevate the entire experience. This is where you stop reading and go get yourself one of these bad boys now.

The space is quite cool looking, with metal gates that lead to a small take out shop. Artwork of pigs and rockets adorn the brick walls. The counter inside the tiny store, displaying multiple slow cooked pork shoulders behind a glass showcase, stands between you and my next major addiction. The cashier was a bit distracted and seemed tuned out, but luckily service was not what I came for. Bought my sandwiches and soup (delicious btw), got back in my car, and pigged out until this porker's belly was stuffed.

If you are one of those people who thinks that Philadelphia has got something on us New Yorkers when it comes to  sandwiches, one bite of Rocket Pig and I doubt you will ever feel that way again. Bring on the Philly cheesesteak. Let the Italian roast pork give it a go. Baltimore's pit beef? They got nothing on this baby. I will take this porky goodness any day over those second rate sandwiches. Oink! Oink! Blast off!
review.author: Gordon Y.

review.description:
Rocket Pig is definitely more geared for takeaway or delivery. The space is small and doesn't have seating. The original sandwich is large and filling. The pork is tender and juicy. The BBQ sauce is quite tasty. A bit too sweet for me. The hot sauce added some nice flavour, but it wasn't spicy at all. It tempered the sweetness of the sauce though. The bread is toasted and soft.
I recommend Rocket Pig for a quick lunch.
review.author: Jem S.

review.description:
This place is soooo good! A legit hole in the wall spot where you order to-go and then eat on the High Line which is just steps away. The Pignic box is packed with the perfect meal: rocket pig sandwich, pickle, coleslaw, choice of chips, dessert & soda. I'd highly recommend the bacon caramels for your dessert option. It's this unexpectedly amazing blend of sweet + smokey + savory that's probably the best "candy" I've ever had. 

The rocket pig sandwich is cooked to absolute perfection and just melts in your mouth. Just listen to its description: smoked, spice-rubbed pork on ciabatta roll with red onion jam and mustard sauce, house-made pickle and side of rocket pig hot sauce. Yummmmm. It's a bit on the smaller side, but if you get the full Pignic meal it's pretty filling in the best way. 

Seriously one of my favorite summer time eats spots. Oh and they also serve wine and beer to stay :)
review.author: Josie T.

review.description:
Their Rocket Pig sandwich was AH-Mazing!

The smoked spice rubbed pork really tasted great with the red onion jam and mustard sauce. 

I typically don't like mustard but I didn't taste it in the sandwich at all probably because of the strong flavors of red onion jam and smoked spice. The pork was tender and juicy. 

Eating this was a messy affair and I had some pork fall out of the sandwich because it was stuffed with lots of meat. I'm glad the cashier gave me a wet wipe and 2 napkins to go with the sandwich because I definitely needed it.

The location is kind of small and if you want to eat there you'd have to stand up and eat it as there are no chairs.
review.author: Teresa C.

review.description: Beyond delicious!!! Best pork sandwich I've ever had. The place itself is super small/ narrow and simple and there isn't seating. They do have counter tops inside and outside to stand and eat though. My bf got the original and I got the box so we can share the fixings that come with the box (it comes with the original, dill pickle, vinegar based slaw, a choice of chips, drink and dessert. Choice of dessert is a brownie, cookie, bacon caramels and hazelnut cookies) We ate right there on the countertop inside so we can have the sandwich while it was hot. I am not lying when I tell you that there were fireworks in my mouth as soon as I took the first bite. The pork is SO beyond juicy, tender and flavorful. The flavors of the pork mix harmoniously with the slightly sweet red onion jam and mustard sauce. Everything just worked SO well and each bite just got better and better. It definitely can get messy if you are not a "dainty eater" like my boyfriend likes to call himself. I, on the other hand, had sauce running down my hands- do not worry, they have wet naps to clean yourself up with. The slaw and pickle was refreshing to eat with the loaded meat sandwich and the chips gave the perfect crunch. Nothing beats the combination of a sandwich and chips. This sandwich by the way is full of meat and a hefty portion but I would not get the smaller size, its just THAT good. However, I was beyond stuffed at the end. But not stuffed enough to try my dessert. I opted for the hazelnut cookies which were so decadent and chocolately. My type of dessert. I will most DEFINITELY be back.
review.author: Hyesil C.

review.description: Second visit and it just gets better and better. The sandwich is so juicy and fresh. Bread is perfectly baked and portions are fanatic. Do yourself a favor and get a sandwich here and eat at the entes portion of the high line.
review.author: J. D.

review.description: As a resident of the mystical region classified fondly as "below the Mason-DIxon line" I feel quite qualifies to say this BBQ can go toe-to-toe with some of the best in the south. Although this place is tiny (when I say "tiny" I'm not talking "omg I live in a one bedroom in hells kitchen and it's so tiny" or "have you ever flown out of Islip? It's TINY!" I am talking 8' across and maybe 12' of standing room to order tiny) and serves up a mean pig. The menu is small and straightforward and the sandwiches take you to another level of nirvana. Smokey, sweet, mustard sauce, ciabatta, hot sauce... why are you still reading this? Go to rocket pig. Worship at the alter of her brilliance and indulge in the delicacy of real American Barbecue!
review.author: Matt K.

review.description:
This review is from August 2016.

This is one of those off the beaten path favorites that you all have. I like this place, for its location and nitch. 

It's perfect for a planned or spontaneous picnic at Chelsea Pier Park. The Pignic provides so much food! Perfect for the day outdoors.

The amount of food provided is amazing:
Sandwich, pickle, Cole slaw, bottle of soda, cookies or brownies and bag of chips all for a whopping $20. 

The sandwich is pretty good, although I don't like the onion jam. It's too sweet and over powers the porkiness of the sandwich.

If I am in the area I would definitely stop by again!
review.author: Shea G.

review.description:
I just like saying it. Rocket Pig.

Rocket..PIG!!!!

Walking up to this place is a little tricky. I see people eating in a nice looking garden. My first reaction? Man, these folks are way too clean to be eating Rocket Pig. (Rocket Pig)

I walk into this tiny tiny space. I see the counterperson and ask him do I order first and then eat over there? He said, yeah grab a table. Great! I walk into the garden party and ask for a menu. The menu doesn't reflect Rocket Pig. (Rocket Pig) The waiter comes over and I said this isn't a BBQ menu, what gives? Oh you want to eat at Rocket Pig (Rocket Pig) You have to order from the counter. I walk back inside and said Dude, what the heck? He said YOU SAID you wanted, I stopped him. I'm hungry and I want to order food from Rocket Pig (Rocket Pig), where do I eat? Oh this place is either to go or stand outside by our small table shelf. I ate MREs, I can stand to eat Rocket Pig (Rocket Pig)

I ordered the Pignic Box! It comes in a cool, carry box. Lets break it down:

- Pork sammy: That's a migh-t-fine cooked pork sammy. Served on a nice big ciabatta bun, they slathered it with caramelized onions. This was a juicy, porky sandwich. The cole slaw was served in a separate container, it had a vinegary taste that cut the fatty BBQ meat. It worked well together.

The drink choices were limited, Sprite, diet Coke and Pellegrino Limonite, I chose the sparkling Limonite.

North Fork chips - BBQ or Sweet Potato. I chose SP

Finally desserts. I was so looking forward to the bacon caramel, sold out. As a matter of fact, the counter person said I had the last Ciabatta bun?? I'm assuming this place gets hit hard during lunch time so plan accordingly. For my dessert I chose the brownie. I just got home and saved this sucka to split with my wife. 

OMG! This brownie was sooooooo good! 

I'm a total fan of Rocket Pig (Rocket Pig) If you want to come for lunch, come early!
review.author: Bill S.

review.description:
I've passed by Rocket Pig many a time because it's on my running path over to the West Side Highway, but I finally walked over and picked up a sandwich from here. I mistook it for Trestle on Tenth many a time, which is right on the corner; the entrance to Rocket Pig is on 24th Street and leads into a very narrow shop - enough space for a few standing spots at a countertop along the side. With exposed brick everywhere, it does feel like a literal hole in the wall, although there is outdoor seating you can park yourself at, weather permitting. The menu is pretty straightforward - the sandwiches are the star of the show (with the salad being the other main of note), with a number of sides. We both went with the sandwich and soup combo, which we figured (correctly) would leave us adequately filled, and we grabbed a brownie to snack on while waiting for the sandwiches.

There's no question that the sandwiches are excellent, and the bread is fantastic to boot. The pork is really juicy and succulent - there's a reason you get a wet wipe with the sandwich - and the picked mustard and aioli really round out what is a very aromatic, flavorful, and decadent sandwich. The bread is worth noting; despite being crispy, it doesn't scratch the roof of your mouth like you might expect, and the texture is a nice complement to the tenderness of the brined pork. The soup is pretty straightforward as well, and it's lighter than I would have guessed, based on how rich the pork meat in the sandwich was. With a heavily smoke-infused flavor, it's pretty much pork broth at its purest, with a few veggies and some bits of pork meat added in. It's a tad on the salty side, but it's quite refreshing next to the sandwich. The brownie was pretty standard-issue, although I did like the subtle hint of espresso that it had without overpowering the chocolate in the brownie. It was a little dried out, but given it was lighter on the butter, that was not necessarily a bad thing.

Even though it does not look like much on the outside, Rocket Pig is definitely worth a stop. Don't expect a lot of variety, but what they do here, they do really, really well...one of the many great sandwich spots in NYC.
review.author: Asuka N.

review.description:
The combination of sauces were perfect, the meat was fattier than I'd like, but the bread soaked all of it up  Order the pignic to get the best of everything for a great price.  The pickles were also amazing and cut through the fattiness of the meat very well!

Really wish they had some seating and longer hours (I would eat this for dinner/late night all the time if I could). I will definitely be back
review.author: Julia S.

review.description:
Went inside the place that said 'eat in' ....me & my bf were going to get the food to go but decided to just eat there since it was rainy outside. Don't expect any chairs though!!...there's only a long table against the wall where you have to stand to eat
We were already pretty full but wanted to try the sandwiches here so we ordered 1 rocket pig sandwich & each ate half a slice.
You have the try the sandwiches here !! I would've gotten my own sandwich if I had room in my stomach...they are pretty amazing!!! The meat was very juicy..every bite was flavorful.
This place didn't disappoint!!
review.author: Sylvia B.

review.description: Ready for your taste buds to blast off? You will love Rocket Pig to the moon and back. This sandwich instantly vaulted into my top 5 sandwiches of all time. Perfect smoky juicy pieces of pork slathered with a homemade jam transported me out of this world. Houston, we have a problem because it'll be tough finding another sandwich this delicious.
review.author: Alexander W.

review.description: Heart attack on a plate? Yes. But as long as you don't eat this every day, get ready for one of the best sandwiches you've ever had. Great bread, perfectly cooked and seasoned pork (sucks for you if you're Halal or Kosher - guess God doesn't like ypu), sautéed purple onions, little sweet/sour BBQ sauce and Kewpie mayo. Hits all the flavor profiles and they are balanced. Damn, now get me a Lipitor
review.author: Rick o.

review.description: The place is tiny but the food is awesome. I had the rocket pig sandwich, chiabatta was on point, and the hazelnut mousse cake, so good. It's in a tiny location, I initially just walked past it without even noticing it. But totally worth it.
review.author: Matthew H.

review.description:
Thank you chef for a beautiful meal, 
Each dish had a unique taste that brings you back memories, as a chef that's taste and feeling that we work so hard to achieve.
The presentation was on point on each plate, going through each dish it felt like heart and soul was put into every plate, 
Thank you Chef
review.author: Marlon C.

review.description:
This place is pretty much perfect. The fresh flowers on the table are an elegant touch that enhances the vibe of the meal and also plays on the freshly prepared nature of all of the simply elegant dishes that the chef prepares.

With all that being said, I came to this seemingly hidden Bushwick spot with 0 expectations. A friend invited me to a spot that her best friend co-managed and I wasn't even very hungry nor did I want to spend much money (I'd gladly come back and give them all of my money).  Where do I begin? I was privileged enough to meet the chef as there is an open kitchen located towards the front of the restaurant. Passerbys can look in (and creepily take pictures from the street) at the chef and his small staff hard at work preparing greatness. There's front window countertop style seating, and then a lightly generous amount of seating for at least one decent sized group and a smaller one of individual date night type situations.

The food is amazing!  I (heavily) sampled like 5 different dishes and they were all equally amazing with no exaggeration. The names are hard to remember but I took photos of each and got the name right in the pictures so peruse them at the bottom of this review. A standout was the mushroom appetizer with the fried egg. It was the best thing I'd eaten all month and i typically don't like mushrooms and I was so reluctant to try it. I'd go back just for it.  The pasta is perfectly made. Also the charcuterie is spot on and delicious. I was so busy enamored by the food that I missed the drink menu completely so I have no clue what they have to offer in that department. Vegetarians are welcomed also.

I'm going back soon!
review.author: Keilon L.

review.description:
Love  this place. The first time I dined here, was on a double date with friends. The wine was flowing, as was the conversation. It was a great wind down after the stresses of work. 

I had the squid ink pasta, which I usually like with a cream sauce so I wasn't blown away. But I had a bite of my friend's carbonara and immediately wanted to come back for more. 

So here I am with bae, taking a break from packing up our apartment, looking forward to our move to the other side of Brooklyn, excited for new beginnings and for the noms we are about ensue. 

And the server just brought us an Amuse Bouche!! What a nice surprise. 

The pasta is fresh, drink as much wine as you can bring in the door, and have a good laugh with a lover or friends. Major noms!
review.author: Niq L.

review.description:
Noticed this was a new restaurant addition on Irving for a few months and finally had the chance to pop in for an early dinner. The interior is small and quaint, one of the nicer, newer and semi upscale restaurants on the block with plenty of natural light coming in from their all window store front. Inside seats probably around 20 and a few stool seats against the window. Since they are a new establishment and still working out their liquor license (I'm assuming), they welcome BYOB with no corkage fee!

All of their pasta is made fresh in house and everything on the menu sounded really tasty. At first glance of their Yelp pics, I thought their servings were a little on the smaller side. I went with the papperdelle dish which came with duck ragu, black raisins and parmesan. The duck was tender and complimented the al dente texture of the papperdelle well. I do wish it was a little more saucy, but it was light and airy. It turned out to be a good amount, I was full but not overly stuffed.

My friend had the fetuccine carbonara, asparagus, crispy pancetta with an egg yolk. We also decided to share a side of the charred broccolini which was a nice fresh balance to our pasta. We both enjoyed our meal and were too full for dessert, but I also hear they make all their dessert from scratch so will have to try next time!

Overall had a good experience here. The server was very knowledgable about their menu and checked in on us often. Great addition to the Bushwick neighborhood that offers a unique dining experience you'd typically have to go to the city for.
review.author: Georgina G.

review.description:
Very good service!i loved burrata for appetizer!We ordered 2 pasta.they were Delicious fresh pasta but I need more sauce.both of them were too light.apple and vanilla ice cream was delicious!
I will come back to try another pasta:)
review.author: Mia Q.

review.description:
Totally shocked that the place was empty at 12:30 pm on this gorgeous Saturday but so not complaining that this cute little gam had no astronomical wait time - they do take reservations btw as we're told dinner time gets pretty busy and the space is small. 
Nicandra's is cozy, and inviting, and unpretentious.  Love the music too!
The brunch menu had so many amazing choices, had the hardest time making decisions - too bad "items 1 through 7 please" wasn't a realistic option!  Great to see a brunch menu that consists of things other than your usual steak and eggs (though that is present) and french toast.  
We decided on a burrata with prosciutto as an appetizer; as for entrees it was polenta with shrimp ragu and poached eggs, and black ink linguini with shrimp.  Everything was simply perfection - the buttery softness of the burrata, perfectly poached eggs over creamy polenta with "just enough of a kick" ragu, flawlessly executed homemade black ink linguini.  For dessert, my friend couldn't resist the crepes with fruits - did not disappoint.  
Nothing like a great brunch to set the rest of the day! Thank you Nicandra's, we'll be back!
review.author: Tatyana R.

review.description:
My girlfriend and I went here Friday night. I had finally tracked down some cash that was owed to me, and was trying to spend it as quickly as possible on the most sumptuous of meals. Alas, though Nicandra's fit the bill on the latter, it was quite affordable!

I called Friday afternoon for an 8:30 PM reservation, and Charmaine put me down. As it turns out, Charmaine works the whole house:  She sat us when we came in, and then served us the entire meal. She was extremely kind and personable.

We started with the burrata and the glazed pork ribs. The burrata was excellent, freshly kneaded and atop a bed of tiny, cool fresh greens. The pork ribs all but changed my world. Huge portion, so tender that when you forked them the meat slid cleanly away from the bone, and desperately needed by my lady and I, as we'd allowed ourselves to get a little shaky before the 8:30 start time.

For dinner, we split the pappardelle and the gnudi -- Charmaine's first- and third-favorites, mind you. The pappardelle was the freshest pasta I've had in some time. The raisins made my girlfriend, upon discovery, squeal with the delight. The sweetness and texture paired so well with this dish. The gnudi was excellent, too -- similar to what you might think of as a 'gnocchi', and topped with a huge portion of braised oxtail. Filling and delicious. We just passed our bowls back and forth throughout the meal like savages. 

BYOB. At the lady's request, I'd brought along a bottle of "Sav B", which paired nicely with our choices. Though at the end of the meal, our booze buzz paled in comparison to the high we got from such a choice culinary experience. I'm NOT a pasta aficionado, but this food, to me, is even better than Missy Robbins's Lilia -- if that means anything to you. Regardless, Nicandra's is taking the Myrtle-Wyckoff food scene to the next level.
review.author: Chad T.

review.description:
Cozy intimate vibe, good music and tasty eats.

I dined with my gf and 2 friends for dinner this past wknd- the joint is tiny, so reservations are key if you plan to dine on yhe wknd.

For Apps we had:

Wild Mushroom w/Egg (my absolute favorite!!)

Braised Porkchops (super tender and a nice portion size perfect for a table of 4)

Crudo (this was OK- it was likely our mistake for pairing it with the heavier savory items- the flavors were refreshing, lots of fruity notes)

For Entrees we had:

3 of us had the squid ink pasta and 1 of us ordered the carbonara with egg.

The squid ink pasta was tasty, although I was hoping the sauce would be a bit more rich/creamy. It's also kinda spicey which was nice- not a dealbreaker, but ill likely order something else next time.

My friend raved about the Carbonara- we all had a bite and it was pretty tasty.

For dessert we all got Creme Brulee- it was VERY nice. It's my go-to dessert and more recently, it's been hard to find one done right! Nicondra did not disappoint :)

I will certainly be back to see what the chef is up to next. Who can deny fresh pasta?!

I cant. And now, I dont have to :)
review.author: Zen4Life L.

review.description:
Ok so this is in now my favorite restaurant, hands down! The food is amazing! My friend and I went there on a quiet Sunday evening.  We ordered 3 dishes and shared them. We got the Linguini Nero with shrimp, Seared scallops with risotto and asparagus and the Duck Ragu.......there are no words to express how wonderful our food was! We didn't get to meet the chef this time but our waitress Charmaine was great! She gave us great selections.  I'm already trying to get back there!!

Came here earlier today for brunch.....back again for take out.  You just can't beat great food and excellent customer service!!!
review.author: Adriann B.

review.description: Me and my friend wanted to treat ourselves to a meal so we tried this spot out. I got steak and potatoes It was so good I sometimes day dream about eating it again. My friend ordered the ribs which are a must try !!  The waitress was also super nice and had a great energy to her. Will be back again to try their brunch
review.author: Lina R.

review.description: #Excellent food. I also made a friend who was sitting next to me. I was pretty drunk, so I don't remember what we were talking about. But I remember the food was excellent. Even came back the #next day.
review.author: FakeFoodBabyNY C.

review.description: Wow. Excellent for price point. They just got themselves a new regular. Steak and eggs $14 is a wonderful bargain. Attention to detail. Fried sage on the potatoes. Need I say more?
review.author: Dom P.

review.description:
Nicandra's is a new addition to a neighborhood full of new additions, but this place really stands out. I wandered in one night and everything was so good I came back a few days later with friends. Whether you are popping in for a solo dinner, going out on a hot date or coming with friends, Nicandra's is perfect and guaranteed to please.

Get the pork ribs appetizer. Oh. Mah. Gah. The meat is cooked in a sweet/savory sauce and falls off the bone. I also tried the mushroom appetizer, which was delicious and I had a few bites where the two dishes had mixed together on my plate. OMG. Yum. 

The chef makes his own pasta every day and you can certainly tell. Each dish is lovingly made - you can tell he cares about every bite you are going to take. It is like being at someone's home (if you happen to know someone who is a very very good cook). 

The service is as warm as the pasta dishes and it's just a really great experience. 

They are working in their liquor license, so its BYO for now. I'm looking forward for a few days to pass so I can come back for lunch or dinner and not seem like a stalker.
review.author: Jennifer S.

review.description:
I've had brunch and dinner here and both meals were excellent. 

The two brothers running the place are incredibly  kind, the food they're serving is amazing and the value is unbeatable. The fresh pasta is as good as what you get at a fine dining place in Manhattan but for half the price. 

I'm looking forward to coming back with a couple of friends so we can try everything on the menu. 

I'm already
review.author: Orion T.

review.description: Handmade fresh pasta. Unique and delicious menu items. Friendly courteous service. The new Bushwick restaurant is a fun cozy new spot every food lover should try out. The menu had several items that sounded appetizing and the lighting is great for some food photography I'm just saying
review.author: Gabriel R.

review.description:
Delicious food. Great service. 
We ordered the burrata and he mushrooms for appetizers. Then the lobster pasta and it was incredible. Dessert was also excellent. 
My new fave place.
review.author: Biancs R.

review.description:
If you've ever found yourself looking for a dope Korean food joint in Bushwick, Sandobe just opened. 

If you've a hankering for great Italian food however, come check out Nicandra's. Run by two brothers, but you wouldn't be able to tell with the amount of great food they're putting out. Pasta are hand-rolled/made (I don't really know how they're made) as well. 

No liquor license yet so it's BYOB for now, but you didn't hear it from me
review.author: Linh N.

review.description:
Food was good. Pasta was fresh and it definitely hit the spot. Seating is awkward but the good service makes up for it. Def a welcome to the hood.
Edit: second time around. Even better than the first time. 4 to 5 star transformation. This time we BYOB'ed some red wine. What a gem of a restaurant.
review.author: Benjamin K.

review.description:
A prime example of a neighborhood gem.

Nicandra's is small, warm, welcoming with delicious food made and served with love and attention.

Our hostess/server was delightful and the ambience is there without trying too hard.

Been meaning to try it since it opened and finally got there. Will be sure to be back soon.
